introduction.p:
In this activity, we will explore a simple model that creates a family tree. Later, we will adapt this argument to understand the threshold for the giant component of a random graph.
We let X_t denote the size of the t-th generation in the family tree.
At time t=0, there is one individual. So X_0=1.
At time t=1, she gives birth to X_1 children and dies.
At time t >2, each of the X_{t-1} individuals in generation t-1 give birth and die. This results in a total of X_t children in the t-th generation.
Here is an example of the branching process.

The number of children Y produced by each individual is an independent random variable governed by (the same) probability distribution. The expected number of children produced is
\E[Y] = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} k \P[Y=k] = \mu.
The goal of this activity will be to show that \mu determines the probability of whether the family tree dies out after a finite number of generations, or if it grows infinitely large.

statement.p:
Use induction on t \geq 0 to prove that X_n, the size of the n-th generation satisfies
\E[X_n] = \mu^n
We have E[X_0] = 1 = \mu^0. Assuming that \E[X_n] = \mu_n, we have
\E[X_{n+1}] &= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \E[X_{n+1} \mid X_{n} = k] \P[X_{n} = k] = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} k \mu \, \P[X_{n} = k]
&= \mu \, \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} k \, \P[X_{n} = k] = \mu \, \E[X_n] = \mu \cdot \mu_n = \mu^{n+1}.

exercise.title: Expected Size of the Tree After n Generations

idx.h: Expected Size of the Tree After n Generations

statement.p:
Let \displaystyle{Z_n= \sum_{t=0}^{n} X_t} be the total number of individuals in the family tree at time n.
Use linearity of expectation to prove that
\E[Z_n] = 1 + \mu + \mu^2 + \cdots + \mu^n.
Using linearity of expectation, we have
\E[Z_n] = \E \left[ \sum_{t=0}^n X_t \right] = \sum_{t=0}^n \E \left[ X_t \right] = \sum_{t=0}^n \mu^t
Confirm that the formula in the previous problem is equivalent to
\E[Z_n] = \frac{\mu^{n+1} -1}{\mu -1}.
Using the formula from part (a), this statement is equivalent to
(\mu -1) ( \mu^n + \mu^{n-1} + \cdots + \mu +1) = \mu^{n+1} -1.
When we expand, we see that all the terms cancel out except for the first term \mu^{n+1} and the last term -1.

Now let's look at the asymptotic behavior of the size of the tree. Let
\E [Z] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \E[Z_n] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\mu^{n+1} -1}{\mu -1}.
Confirm that if \mu < 1 then \E[Z] is finite. Then find a formula for \E[Z].
If \mu < 1 then \mu^{n+1} \rightarrow 0, so
\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \E[Z_n] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\mu^{n+1} -1}{\mu -1} = \frac{-1}{\mu-1} = \frac{1}{1- \mu}.
Confirm that if \mu > 1 then \E[Z] is infinite.
If \mu > 1 then \mu^{n+1} \rightarrow \infty, so
\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \E[Z_n] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\mu^{n+1} -1}{\mu -1} = \infty.

We say that \mu =1 is a threshold for whether the family tree dies out. This is because
if \E[Z] is finite then \P[ \mbox{there exists } N \mbox{ such that } X_N = 0]=1.
Show that this is true by proving the contrapositive statement:
if \P[ X_t \geq 1 \mbox{ for all t} ]=\alpha > 0 then \E[Z] is infinite.
We have
\P[ X_t \geq 1 \mbox{ for all } t \geq 0] = \alpha >0.
But then
\E[Z_n] = \sum_{t=0}^n \E[X_t] \geq \sum_{t=0}^n \P[X_t \geq 1] = \sum_{t=0}^n \alpha = \alpha (n+1)
and so
\E[Z] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \E[Z] = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \alpha (n+1) = \infty.
